Entonces, claro, aunque había ciertas áreas de la medicina barroca que poco a poco fueron tolerando el uso del tabaco como una hierba medicinal, que el aroma, el humo, no sé qué, que podía tratar organismos débiles o melancólicos, también había como cierta sensación de placer y de estar un poquito adormilada y de satisfacción, que todo eso chocaba de frente con los códigos morales de la época. So, of course, although there were certain areas of baroque medicine that little by little tolerated the use of tobacco as a medicinal herb, that the aroma, the smoke, I don't know what, that it could treat weak or melancholic organisms, there was also a certain sensation of pleasure and of being a little bit sleepy and of satisfaction, which all clashed head-on with the moral codes of the time. Siempre los hombres con un tizón en las manos y ciertas hierbas para tomar sus saumerios, que son unas hierbas secas metidas en una cierta hoja, seca también, a manera de mosquete hecho de papel, de los que hacen los muchachos la pascua del Espíritu Santo. Él lo explica todo en su terreno. y encendida por la una parte de él, por la otra chupan, osorben o reciben con el resuello para adentro aquel humo con el cual se adormecen las carnes y casi en borracha. Y así diz que no se sienten el cansancio. Estos mosquetes, o como los llamaremos, llaman ellos tabacos, Españoles conocí yo en esta isla española que los acostumbraron a tomar, que siendo reprendidos por ello, diciéndoles que aquello era vicio, respondían que no era en su mano dejarlos de tomar, no sé qué sabor o provecho hallaban en ello.
text_en: They are quite fascinating. So, Columbus in his diaries mentions the mysterious appearance of tobacco in a rather curious way that I'm going to read it to you. He says... that there were two Christians who were going around, well, swarming, raping women, doing what they were doing, and he says, these two Christians found along the way many people going through their villages, women and men. Always the men with a wood in their hands and certain herbs to take their saumerios, which are some dried herbs put in a certain leaf, also dry, like a musket made of paper, of which the boys make the passover of the Holy Spirit. He explains it all in his land. and ignited by the one part of it, by the other they suck, osorben or receive with the breath inside that smoke with which the meats are numbed and almost in drunkenness. And thus it is said that they do not feel the fatigue. These muskets, or as we shall call them, they call them tabacos. I knew Spaniards in this Spanish island who were accustomed to take them, who being reprimanded for it, telling them that it was a vice, replied that it was not in their power to stop taking them, I do not know what flavor or benefit they found in it.

text: Define tabaco así. Id pensando cómo lo definiréis vosotras, porque Cobarrubia os dice qué es. Hierba bastantemente conocida, que reducida en polvo, se toma para expeler las humedades del cerebro. Algunos le coman buscando el gusto que perciben o aprenden en el olfato, con tanto vicio que no faltó quien dijese que tiene hechizo por ver la fatiga y solicitud con que lo buscan. y se melancolizan estos cofrades del tabaco cuando les falta. Pero hemos de confesar que no es más que vicio porque no intenta hacer o saber algo por pacto explícito o implícito con el demonio requisitos que piden un hechizo. El primero que la descubrió fue el demonio, haciendo tomarlo a sus sacerdotes y ministros cuando habían de profetizar lo que les consultaban y el demonio les descubría lo que alcanzaban por conjeturas mediante aquella cualidad atontados. O sea, Cobarrubias tiene aquí un matiburrillo, que es una hierba, que por un lado me hace mucha gracia lo de que los cofrales que fuman tabaco se melancolizan si no lo encuentran.
text_en: Define tobacco like this. Think about how you will define it, because Cobarrubia tells you what it is. It is a well known herb, that reduced in powder, is taken to expel the humidities of the brain. Some eat it looking for the taste that they perceive or learn in the sense of smell, with so much vice that some say that it has a spell to see the fatigue and solicitude with which they seek it, and these brothers of tobacco become melancholy when they lack it. But we must confess that it is nothing more than vice because it does not try to do or know something by explicit or implicit pact with the devil requirements that ask for a spell. The first one who discovered it was the devil, making his priests and ministers take it when they had to prophesy what they consulted them and the devil discovered them what they reached by conjectures by means of that quality, being stunned. That is to say, Cobarrubias has here a matiburrillo, which is a herb, that on the one hand makes me a lot of fun that the brothers who smoke tobacco become melancholy if they do not find it.

Entonces enseguida, claro, pues tú piensas Ya lo decía Cobarrubias, que dice, el que inventó el tabaco fue el demonio, y toda la cadena de significantes, fuego, humo, prácticas diabólicas.

Basically what is going to happen throughout the XVI and XVII centuries is that tobacco is valued for certain therapeutic uses, but at the same time there is a constant desire to debase indigenous practices and the hedonistic and paralyzing qualities of tobacco are being highlighted all the time. Then immediately, of course, you think, as Cobarrubias said, that it was the devil who invented tobacco, and the whole chain of signifiers, fire, smoke, diabolical practices.

text: Hay un médico, que a mí me cae muy bien, que se llama Nicolás Monardes. Tu amigo. Independientemente, Monardes escribe un tratado sobre botánica y plantas medicinales y demás y él enseguida lo que hace es conectar el tabaco con el universo de las profecías y es básicamente como una nueva industria vegetal que según Monardes está empleada por el diablo para introducir el pecado en las comunidades indígenas. O sea, la película que se ha montado Monardes es tremenda. Y describe con mucho detalle los rituales que utilizaban en las comunidades indígenas utilizando el tabaco y dice cosas como, por ejemplo, dice, recibí el humo por la boca y entomándolo caí en el suelo como muerto. Y luego enseguida dice, cuando había hecho la hierba su obra, recordaba, es decir, se despertaba y dábales las respuestas conforme a los fantasmas ilusiones que mientras estaba de aquella manera veía. O sea, todo 100% profético.
text_en: There is a doctor, whom I like very much, whose name is Nicolás Monardes. Your friend. I like him because he writes a treatise, well, for something else, but he writes a treatise in which he praises the virtues of iron against gold, because he says, gold is useless and iron is useless for many things. Independently, Monardes writes a treatise on botany and medicinal plants and so on and he immediately connects tobacco with the universe of the prophecies and it is basically like a new vegetable industry that according to Monardes is used by the devil to introduce sin in the indigenous communities. In other words, the movie that Monardes has put together is tremendous. And he describes in great detail the rituals used in the indigenous communities using tobacco and he says things like, for example, he says, I received the smoke through my mouth and I fell to the ground as if I were dead. And then he goes on to say, when the herb had done its work, he remembered, that is, he woke up and gave them the answers according to the phantom illusions that he saw while he was in that way. In other words, all 100% prophetic.

O sea, en los casos inquisitoriales relacionados, en los que aparece como el chocolate, una presencia constante es el miedo Porque de hecho era una práctica habitual, al parecer, a que mujeres utilizaran el chocolate como producto con el que enmascarar otros ingredientes utilizados normalmente en pócimas o engüentos de brujería, que además del chocolate lo que estaban enmascarando era sangre, orina... excrementos, o polvo de huesos animales, polvo, pelo, o sea, lo que fuera, ¿no? Pues para que no se notara la presencia de todo eso, el chocolate era muy útil. Hay un caso en 1668, pues, o sea, ya es tardecito, pero aún así se veía sucediendo. El santo oficio interroga a una mujer española que reconoce, es muy tierno, ya reconoce que sí, que había usado el chocolate, que bebía su esposo, para meter ahí cositas, polvitos, cositas mágicas suyas. ¿Y para qué? Es que esto me dio ternura. Ella quería que el marido se bebiera este vaso de chocolate con pocio de uva mágica, adulterado. para romper el vínculo que su esposo tenía con su mejor amigo.
text_en: It's just that it's very curious because it's the opposite with chocolate. Like, from what I have read, which again, I insist, I have not done a thesis on chocolate at this time. But it does seem, I mean, there is this permanent association between chocolate, women, witchcraft. In other words, in the related inquisitorial cases, in which chocolate appears, a constant presence is the fear, because in fact it was a common practice, apparently, for women to use chocolate as a product with which to mask other ingredients normally used in potions or witchcraft ointments, that besides chocolate what they were masking was blood, urine... excrement, or animal bone dust, dust, hair, that is, whatever, right? Well, in order not to show the presence of all that, chocolate was very useful. There is a case in 1668, well, I mean, it is a little late, but it was still happening. The Holy Office interrogates a Spanish woman who admits, it is very sweet, she admits that yes, she had used the chocolate, which her husband drank, to put in it little things, little powders, little magic things of hers. And what for? This made me feel tender. She wanted her husband to drink this glass of chocolate with magic grape powder, adulterated, to break the bond that her husband had with his best friend.
